trial_identification.studytitle: Iron REplacement ADvice Study in female donors aged 18-45 years
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The acceptance and feasibility of iron replacement advice for female whole blood donors aged 18-45 years.

interventions.interventions:
Consented participants will be provided with a brochure prior to their donation which provides advice on how to replenish iron stores after a whole blood donation. The information is provided at each eligible visit during the study period. Adherence and acceptability will be monitored using a specifically designed questionnaire at 6 weeks after the recruitment visit and again 6 weeks after the 11-13 month visit if the donor attends at this time.
Donors are provided with a study contact number to assist with any queries that may arise after they leave the donor centre.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Donor acceptance and adherence measured by a questionnaire which has been specifically designed for this study.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: 6 weeks after recruitment visit and 6 weeks after the 11-13 month visit

primaryOutcome.outcome: Operational feasiblity measured with time-and-motion studies and staff questionnaire. The staff questionnaire will address perception regarding impacts on workflow for various areas of the donation process.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Efficacy: Donor - Iron status assessed using serum ferritin
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Ferritin samples at baseline and 11-13 month visit

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Efficacy Operational - based on eligilbity to donate on return visits
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: For the duration of the study period (13 months)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Safety- iron overload based on serum ferritin
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Clinical ferritin taken at the 3rd visit (or after two whole blood donations)

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: -Females aged 18-45 (inclusive) on the day of recruitment -Eligible and intending to donate whole blood -Made at least one whole blood donation (>300mL) in the last -12 months -Able to provide written consent
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Therapeutic donors Autologous donors Donors who are ineligible to donate (including Hb-related deferrals) Donors converted to apheresis on the day of the recruitment visit; and Donors with any of the following: -A history of allergy to iron supplements -A history of hereditary haemochromatosis, iron overload or a known genetic predisposition to these conditions. -A family history of haemochromatosis (and have not been tested to exclude genetic predisposition to the condition); or -Red cell disorders (i.e. thalassaemia trait, sickle cell trait, G6PD deficiency, hereditary spherocytosis, hereditary elliptocytosis)

trial_design.designfeatures: All eligible donors will be invited to participate in the study.
trial_design.statisticalmethods: The samples size was calculated to achieve an appropriate precision (+/-5%) around responses to study questionnaire items, incorporating expected reductions in return rates at subsequent donations and adherence to the study programme.

fundingsource.fundingname: Australian governments fund the Australian Red Cross Blood Service via the National Blood Authority.

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Approximately 220-250 mg of iron is lost with each 470 mL whole blood donation. This may result in progressive iron deficiency, ultimately leading to iron deficiency anaemia and deferral at a subsequent attendance. This study will pilot an education program for high risk donors on how to replenish iron stores after donation. The study will evaluate operational feasibility, donor acceptance and efficacy of this program.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Australian Red Cross Blood Service Human Research Ethics Committee
